It's late 2018, I boot up my Wif- ..I mean Computer, I open my browser, Open Canc- Youtube. My eyes are immediatly drawn to my Recommendation, there I see 'TOP 10 FUNNIEST ANIME MOMENT', Upon seeing I think to myself "Oh fuck, I forgot to sign off my account from my brother's Computer", OFC, I ignore such vile Uncivil bait for views and my lack of Internet Hygine. My taste in comedy can't possibly be sated by thes- I missclicked, anyway the first few minute see a girl being isekai'd by a truck and I immediatly close the video, say fuck you to my Brother,and Forget whatever happens that day. A month later I come to learn that what I've watch is the first few minute of an anime called 'Zombie land saga', and that's how I start the show. Long winded Explanation that doesn't explain anything? Fuck you this is my first review, I'm not good with starting these. Anyway, Later on I realize that the anime is EXTREMELY popular, and Immediately told myself to wait for the hype to go down. Where then I Marathon the show in 3 days and here we are! aight let's start the actual review


Story.(8/10)

The overarching plot take a back seat for most of the show, so there isn't much here. I was reluctant to give it a 5< score because of this, but I give it an 8 anyway, seeing how that anything in the story other than the Overarching plot is so good. The overarching plot is there, it's good enough to keep the rest going, but it's prob one of its biggest flaw, only second to its use of CG (more on this later). However, as I've said before, anything other than the overarching plot is really good. The character development especially is very well managed with little to no hiccup. Lore is (Insert joke about season 2 here). Also, I'll give it credit for not giving into the trope of beach Episode fan-service. Overall, if only for the fact that the whole overarching plot being very lacking, I'd give it a perfect score, unfortunately it is, so It's stuck with an eight.


Art(5/10)

Very Very generic, there really isn't that much to talk about here other than a single nitpick and a single praise. Why CG? I know I'm biased here, but why bother with one when you're still capable in doing it with normal 2D animation? I don't get it. In fact The animation overall is very expressive, which makes me wonder even more why they decide to use CG. Don't get me wrong, it isn't lazy, I can see them genuinely trying to make this work,,. But there can only be so much you do with bad CG before the fact that it's bad CG Badly explode allover the Non bad CG part. Overall, I'll give it a mediocre score, I'm eager to give it a 4 but I'll at least give it credit for being very expressive.


Character (9/10)

Ho boy, let me tell you this is THE best part of the show. The Character design, is both elegant and unique, for some you can even see a glimpse of what their previous life were (If you don't know what I mean, read the synopsis), and a clue of how they die. It tease your brain with Visual, rather than a blatant foreshadowing from the Character's line, it tells a story with not only animation and interaction, but also with their character design. That's not all either, every character just like I've said previously, are very expressive, they each (well, most) are very well developed in terms of personality and character. I could wrote more about this, but I don't think I will overstay my welcome here. 


Sound (6/10)

Despite being an 'idol show' The sound design is very very mediocre. The Background soundtrack is 'eh'. The sound composition is fair at best, and at worse; ruin the mood. The only saving grace is the Opening (which sounds better every time I hear it!), anything else is either Mediocre or plain bad.


Enjoyment (9/10)

Despite all this flaws, did I enjoy it? Of fuking course I did! I watch it after the hype is over and I complete it in 3 days, why would you think I rush an Uninteresting show and write a review about it? There's nothing better than having high expectation and seeing it not disappoint. It's doesn't take itself too seriously, it doesn't feel like a rushed job, The CG and sound composition kinda ruins the mood but I'll manage. I got so hooked into it that I almost want to continue with other Idol show! Almost. You heretic will never turn me into one of your kind.


Overall, I will say it's really really amazing. Will it turn me into an Idol fan? Probably not, I think the show work not because of it being an Idol show, but because of it's good writing. This might just be because I have never watch an Idol show before, which means I don't know what make an Idol show enjoyable. In fact maybe the whole reason I enjoy the show is because it's an Idol show and I'm just a bias asshole who can't see thing for what they are. But I digest. Spectre Estate Epic is a great show last season, and nothing will change my mind. The show is over, it's finished, there's no unexplained plot points that make us want another season. It's complete. Right?

[If you can, please watch the show before reading this. I discuss some elements that surprised me and I wouldn't want those surprises ruined for you]
Story(9/10): The concept of zombies turned into idols is absurd, and this show knows it. The craziness of everything is fully embraced, and that's the strongest part of this show in my opinion. The story is paced expertly well, with each misadventure feeling fun and outrageous while also not skipping out on some of the more heartfelt elements. Perfectly sketchy mastermind Koutarou's main goal, the revitalization of Saga, allows for a free-flowing plot that pummels the viewer with pure fun.I was pleasantly surprised by the touching plot-lines sprinkled in the 2nd half of the show. I loved the direction everything went in episodes 10-12 in particular. Overall, Zombieland Saga's story is packed with just the right amounts of mayhem and heart, but don't expect anything groundbreaking.


Art(9/10): Goddamned fantastic. Even though the show's main focus is the dead everything feels so alive. (I really hope I'm the first to say that.) I haven't seen animation this slick since Kill La Kill. The range of motion the animators painstakingly added to these characters is outstanding. From Saki's abruptly intimidating body-language to Tae's hunger-fueled frenzy, movement is an absolute joy to watch. Everything else is great, namely the vibrant backgrounds along with the constant changes in the main cast's costumes. The jarring flaw that prevented art from being a complete 10 is the distracting CGI dances. I do not know much about animation, but I have to assume that animating choreography is a pain in the ass. I understand the transition to CGI for the more complex dancing scenes, but man, does it stick out like a sore thumb. I could probably count the CGI scenes on one hand, and there are some dances that don't have it, however I wished the quality was much better than it turned out because the characters look uncomfortably close to MMD quality at times. Overall the animation is fantastic, but the CGI drags the hyped up performances equences down for me.


Sound(10/10): I can't find the words to show how much I love the voice acting. It's wonderful and everyone does a fantastic job. I really appreciated how the voice actresses did not sound like they were drowning in autotune for the songs. Either they were using some pretty damned impressive autotune tech or they have lovely singing talent equivalent to their flawless voice acting skills. The OP is catchy as hell, and the background music (especially that one badass guitar piece for Saki and the other bikers) overall was a pleasure to listen to.


Character(8/10): I thought they would be shallow and I wasn't expecting anything bold, but most of them were decently fleshed out. I loved the exploration into Sakura's mentality during the final three episodes in particular. Saki's and Lily's respective episodes were both great, with appropriately touching moments. Junko's, Ai's, and Yuugiri's plotlines felt reasonably weaker in my opinion because they mainly served as foils to Sakura. These three were the less memorable of the bunch but their stories were decent at best. I also appreciated how Koutarou's source of motivation isn't actually told to you and left to be pieced together by the viewer. The back-and-forth between the characters is what shines the brightest. All the funny moments landed and never felt out of place. I particularly found Koutarou's "good morning's" the funniest. It's comedic when it needs to be and more somber when it needs to be.


Enjoyment(10/10): It's a blast from start to finish. Even though I had minor gripes with characters and art, none of those took anything away from how much I enjoyed this show. 


Overall(10/10): Zombieland Saga has flaws, but its accomplishments in every department overpowered all the problems I had with it. It presents a powerful lesson on perseverance and is one of the funniest shows I've ever watched. It's a fantastic (wow, I've used that word a lot in my review), well-rounded show that gave me everything I wanted from it and also delivered a surprisingly heartfelt story in the end.

[I tried to make this as spoiler free as possible. Feel free to read before watching the anime]
Zombieland Saga is the most underrated anime of 2018. I'm not even exaggerating. It got written off as a generic horror/zombie or idol anime, while in actuality it's a brilliant take on the idol genre, exploring controversial themes, combining them with common idol tropes, art style and music, and packaging them all together in a masterpiece show that only anime can achieve.
This may not be immediately obvious, as Zombieland hides this under the cover of horror and satire, both of which serve to advance the show's main idea.
__________________
ZombielandSaga starts off with our protagonist Sakura, cheerfully running outside of her house holding an interview sheet which will serve to start her idol career, when she suddenly gets hit by the infamous Truck-kun (when will his terror end?). Sakura awakens as a zombie girl in an abandoned house, surrounded by other zombie girls. Our male main character, Tatsumi Koutarou, a loud, obnoxious man, appears, and reveals he has gathered all these girls, each coming from various time periods with various personalities and revived them as zombies so he could make them into idols and save his home prefecture of Saga.


If this premise sounds familiar and ridiculous, that's because it should be. Zombieland is a Konosuba-like parody of the idol industry: 

The girls being zombies is a joke on how hard idols must work to be good at their job, the very distinct and different girls being joined by the power of plot to save something is a joke on the predictable plot of idol anime, and Tatsumi being the way he is, is a joke on how idol managers only care about using the girls as tools.


What's brilliant about Zombieland is how it uses the parody, and the various comedic situations the girls find themselves in, to draw us into the show, and attaches us to the characters. It subtly changes focus from the comedy onto the girls, their development, and how they improve at being idols, until the point where it outright becomes the very type of show it was parodying at the beginning. All without us the viewers not noticing a thing.


Once the focus is changed, Zombieland explores the very unorthodox nature of its idol girls. Unlike the purity and strict guidelines other anime shows follow in terms of their idols, Zombieland has a trans girl, an oiran (19th century Japanese courtesans, often prostitutes), and a badass biker girl.

But despite their background, the show never treats them differently from the other girls. It explores their background while affirming that they have a place in the group as they are. It's a bold move, which criticizes the lack of such characters in other idol anime while at the same time showing how to implement them, and it's highly appreciated.

As the show progresses, we also see Tatsumi change his behavior, treating the girls with more respect and behaving like a proper manager.

In short, it takes very unique and different characters and makes them work together without them losing their individual traits.

__________________


As for animation, it is also, you guessed it, a parody of idol anime, while at the same time being used in the same manner as other idol anime. The show starts off which cheap-looking CGI, poking jokes at the bad CGI most idol anime have at the beginning, and the CGI slowly advances, until it is supplemented by hand drawn animation.

The coreography is detailed and realistic, and yet at the same time anime-like and energetic, as with all idol anime. It's fun to look at, and you might even want to learn the dances.


Finally, I would like to give praise to the art style and music. It's a unique style, simplistic with lots of colors, which makes it easy to immediately differentiate the girls, and always keeps your attention.

The opening is one of the best I've seen, with a brilliant song that is a homage to anime of the 60s and 70s, with upbeat music and lots of violins and trumpets.

The music has variety, with both catchy and soft, bittersweet songs, as with all idol anime. It's something you'd want to listen on a regular basis.


__________________


I highly enjoyed this anime, for two very distinct reasons. At the beginning, I enjoyed its parody and comedy, laughing out loud multiple times, and as the show progressed, I enjoyed its music, characters, and the fact it is an idol anime, the exact thing I was laughing at being parodies.

Zombieland is simply as entertaining as anime can get, and as fun as it can get, both a joke and serious, both happy and sad.


I recommend watching it even to those who hate the idol genre, as it has just enough power to possibly change your opinion.

I don't think I've ever been as blindsided as I have with this one. I only watched one PV before it started airing and even from that I couldn't have even guessed what this was gonna be about. Of all things I didn't expect an idol show at that. Admittedly I've never watched an idol show and this was a pretty fun ride. 
The characters in this show are probably about as tropey as it can get with anime just filling in the blanks with each of our girls and then we get the big hitters. The LEGENDARY YAMADA TAE and the groups producer KoutarouTatsumi (voiced by non other the Mamoru Miyano AKA Okabe Rintaro). Tae had a good role of always being comic relief which is weird to think about in a largely gag concept of "zombie idols" and I wouldn't have it any other way with the antics she gets up to. Koutarou on the other hand is largely shrouded in mystery as to who he is and why he wants to save the Saga prefecture with an idol group whilst simultaneously berating our group in the funniest ways possible with incredible delivery.


Part of me wants to give this an 8 or possibly a 7 just because the dance sequences where done in pretty bad looking CG that made for really jarring cuts back to full animation but I have a feeling that was done intentionally as to mock its other contemporaries in an almost deconstruction nature of idol shows. Deconstruction of Idols is probably the most apt name for this show giving how it handles a lot of the things thrown at it and the cookie cutter nature of it characters. 


If anything it having this quality probably makes this show sit comfortably at a 9 for me. It was a good time every week I tuned in for each episode had great gags, excellent chemistry between our characters and definitely showed off the better parts of idol anime while at the same time bashing it and always had me wondering what our undead girls were gonna get roped into next week.

Art 8: Art could be better for my opinion. But it was good enough. 
Sound 9: First of all the opening and ending are great. Just some good music. But why I give this a 9 isthe music during the serie. Amazing songs and dance I LIKE J-POP.\n\n
Character 10: All of the characters are Great. But the one I do like was Tae Yamada. This girls is nuts. And laugh alot at the last part (but i dont spoil). \n\n
Enjoyment 10: Why? If started watching this with my friends and well. If you chill out and watch it with friends. Its doubles your enjoyment for sure. Comedy was 100% active in this serie. Story just great!!\n\n
Overall 9: Well because zombie saga is just a story about music. This serie is really one to watch. And cant wait for next season. My personal opinion: Its great and you will laugh alot. Or else you are a zombie ;)

When I first started Zombieland Saga, I wasn't sure what to expect. About halfway through it, I almost dropped it. But I'm glad that I finished it. And here's why:
Zombieland Saga is full of comedy and that's why I stuck around for as long as I did. Some of it is repetitive and abrupt but it's this which makes it even funnier (sometimes). The story itself is simple though and some may find this boring. But it's easy to get into even if idol anime isn't your thing. (Trust me, I'm one of those people.) Also, the anime's use of flashbacks near the end ofthe 12th episode made the episode more powerful that it already was.  


And the characterization is good. Not great but good. You learn more about the characters and their backstories as the anime goes on. Unfortunately, some characters weren't very explored. This is kinda obvious considering that we find out more about two of them naturally and the later episodes explore a few other characters in a noticeably episodic manner. This isn't necessarily bad but, because of how the backstories are done later in the series, it's pretty obvious when some of the characters aren't covered. The timing of the main character's backstory was done well in my opinion and I really enjoy being able to notice and learn one thing at a time about a seemingly blank but funny character.  


The art is pretty good; it's bright and looks really nice. The animation is great most of the time but some may not be a big fan of the CGI. The transition between the normal animation and CGI is very noticeable and the speed of it is kinda slow. The characters themselves don't look too bad in CGI though. 


The sound is great. The opening is funny and catchy. The ending song is sweet and nice sounding but it's slow and lacks energy. That's normal for ending songs but it's not something I listen to every episode. The songs they sing together are really good though. It's nice being able to hear the voice actors' singing voices. 


Story: 9

Art: 9

Sound: 10

Character: 8

Enjoyment: 10


Watch this anime from start to finish. It's comedic but becomes inspiring later on. The anime turned itself around and became something I didn't expect. Overall, this anime deserves a 9. I'm going to miss this series a bit.

Story- 9


Art- 10

Overall- 9

This is my 3rd review! I appreciate all who take the time to read my reviews. (Please check out my other reviews!). There were a lot of surprise shows this season, and Zombieland Saga was definitely one of them. I knew kind of the deal going in, but it wasn’t anything I expected!
Let me say that I haven’t watched any idol show (Love Live! IDOLM@STER, etc) ever because I’m not too interested in the genre. This one kind of fooled me, and probably many people thinking it was a full-on parody or satire of the genre. At first, it definitely felt like it was. Iknew a few viewers who were intrigued by it, however as the show went on, some of them felt disappointed as it did turn out to be an ‘idol’ show.

But I stayed, simply because I liked the characters and wanted to know more about them! I guess I can say I was fooled into watching an idol show, but don’t get me wrong, I’m not just about to go watch Love Live! Or another idol show because of this though. 


Story: 8/10


A girl named Sakura suddenly dies and is revived as a zombie, along with other girls. They all seem to be affiliated with idol or some important culture/background. You find out the man behind all of this is Koutarou Tasumi. His goal is to revive the city of Saga with an idol group. At face value the plot does seem a little dull, however as the story goes on each character’s history expands on the main plot. This is what made me appreciate the show a lot. All the girls are dead, and they are revived for a reason. Some stories made me smile, laugh, and even tear up. That’s enough to say it’s a great story. It wasn’t breathtaking but definitely enjoyable. Each episode or two had a little variety which made me curious as to what was coming next week (obviously besides from the ending credit previews).


Character: 8.5/10


Each character was distinctive from the beginning. Their looks and their personality. I really didn’t have a favorite though as all the girls weren’t super interesting to me. What I really took from them was their story and how they became zombies in the first place. I think that history is what made me like each character more in the end. I think they all meshed well together even with how distinct each character is. They all work together, which makes a good group. There were some quality of life side/support characters that reappeared which I thought was neat.

However, I think the sole character that carried the show was definitely Kotarou-san. He himself made this show push the extra mile. He is what made this show interesting and hilarious. Mamoru did an excellent job and I feel like the voice director just told him to go wild. He’s one of my favorite voice actors. Steins;Gate is my favorite show so just the craziness and wackiness of his voice really upped the game for me. His funny English and random outbursts made me laugh too many times watching this. He actually gets a whole point for his performance. This ties in with the sound which I’ll cover later.


Art: 7/10


I’m actually not a big fan of CG, even if it is an ‘idol’ show which has CG, it really just doesn’t vibe with me at all. It’s just so eerie to me so having to watch it was a pretty big turn off. However, I do like each character’s designs, and the art style and techniques I actually liked quite a bit. Each character was distinct and they wore different outfits here and there. Just going back between CG and non-CG was just too much of a juxtaposition. In the end it was a really colorful show and I enjoyed that. But what really kept this score in tact was the opening cinematic. Holy cow! It’s so different I love it. The song is okay, but just what they are doing is awesome!


Sound: 9/10


Voice acting was amazing. You already know how much I praised Mamoru for his performance with Kotarou. Even with how stupid Tae and the police officer sounded, it just went along with the silly tone. Saki with her slang, Yuugiri with her old era tone, each voice was unique. And to be honest, I thought some of the performance songs were catchy. Like I’ve heard Love Live! songs and with how many there are…I think I like one or two, so it’s hard to get my attention with idol songs. I didn’t add them to a playlist or my music library or anything, but they good enough for me to enjoy the performance. Especially Junko’s singing, jeez, that’s a singing voice that I like. As mentioned, the opening and ending songs are forgettable. I think the rap battle in the second episode was definitely one of my favorite episodes that I’ve seen in a while. Sick bars. This episode solidified that I should keep watching. However I was a little disappointed that nothing really got up to this caliber, but it wasn't bad by far.


Enjoyment: 8/10


Whenever we got history on a character or when Koutarou was talking, I really loved it. When there was CG or some drama between the girls, it was definitely a turn off. But it wasn’t enough for me to really dislike the show a lot. I got so caught up wondering how each girl died, and when it’s enough to make me tear up or be surprised, it carries the enjoyment score up. Especially the glimpse of something in the last episode. It literally made me stand up and look wide-eyed to my girlfriend who watches this show with me. I think it was very entertaining and I had a good time watching this show.


Overall: 8/10


For my final thoughts I think it’s a very good show. It’s not bad for what it is. It’s definitely an idol show, but with what I like, it was good enough for me to enjoy it. I’d say give it a shot. I had no experience with an idol show so this was a good first one for me. It’s silly, dramatic, and heartwarming. Adding the score total up it comes to 40.5 out of 50, which is an 8/10 really in the end!


Thanks for reading! I’ll try to put some more out when I can. I appreciate it!

Idol series, a genre that certainly has had its peak in the past years but has also known some steep decrease in popularity in recent years. We really don't see a lot of “good” takes on the genre if hardly any. One could always say it's gotten old or way too repetitive, a bunch of ambitions individuals form up an idol group and strive for fame and success, yeah, I could form the same an assumption if you put it in similar words, but zombies forming an idol group sounds a lot funnier and exciting.
Story (7.5/10):
It takes a lot to maintain a good and consistentplot, and to be honest, “Zombieland Saga” while not of a mature or serious setup and doesn't have a long run to it either is still doing just about decent handling itself in term of consistent writing and story progression.

A bunch of mysterious “idols” from different periods of time gets resurrected somehow into mildly-sane zombies and put in a quest of saving this town called Saga. Don't even ask me how can simply being an idol save anything either.

As we start at the first episode from a blank starting point, we basically know nothing about their world or the main character cast, but just the idea of seeing everybody open up to one another and strengthening their bonds is one quirk of Zombieland Saga that does right, it's nothing to take lightly as to wake up one day and be told that you're dead and are now a zombie, and seeing these girls not only getting over that, but still have a strong spirit to even dare grow as individuals on a greater scale is astonishing, and the sense of achievement that comes throughout the series is just that inspiring.


Art (7.5/10):

For me at least, Zombieland Saga nailed its own art style, I'm confident enough that I could distinguish it from tones of other similar shows, it's just how they play with colors here. So you get theri zombie form that has all of those could and lame colors, and as soon as they put up some makeup to cover that up, you could swear their flesh is now more lively and vibrant, as the colors get stronger and outline them even better.

I feel that it was a shame for a great art style as that to fall short on animation on some of the big moments.

This is a show about idols, so you know it's going to involve some intense performances on the high scale, and they better have some clean shots in store for that, unfortunately, the use of cheap CG really kills the mood sometimes, you'd be having a great close up on a character's face in mid-performance and then it suddenly becomes a really zombie-fest of a visual with those ps2 graphics. Relying on pure 2D would have saved this show a lot of hassle.


Sound (8.5/10):

Music takes a huge cut from this show, so the vocals better be rocking it alright. And that's where I was right.

Unlike the sometimes horrifying visuals, the featured songs were spot on, you could almost get the same excitement of their live audience as if the voice acting cast were some sort of real world band that know what they are doing. Speaking of which, not only their singing sequences were great but also the rest of voice acting, the sad and fun moments were equally emotionally strong, and probably the star there would be Miyano Mamoru that voices the manager Tatsumi (Also famous for voicing Okabe from Steins;Gate).

I really enjoyed both the opening and ending theme songs, the opening was a bit questionable for me as a first exposure, it had that strange mecha-power-rangers feel to it, but it really does stick to the mind and the ending had a really strong nostalgic feel to it, it almost makes you feel bad the show will have to end one day, and it did for me.


Characters (8/10):

Probably what this show nails to the bone the most. Every. Single. Character. Man, that's a lot of favorites, I just can't pick one, they are all superb and similarily fleshed out.

First of all, their design, they do look like a group of idols for starters, and yes, they have that special main character aura to them as well. I really like their attire, and even reflects the period each one of them belonged.

My favorite part was their impactful backstories, I thought I signed up for a fun and goofy show, and I ended up pulling on my third tissue box by the end, man, those were some depressing and reflecting backstories that explained a lot of their individual treats, something I never expected from a show like this, but still appreciated to the core.


Enjoyment (7.5/10):

I'm not big on moe, nor am I that huge on idols shows, I probably only wanted to watch this because I had some extra free time and I needed to fill, I had already picked up more interesting shows and I needed another one just to make it an even number, but I never expected it to rank even higher than other picks, I really had my fair share of laughs, I spared some tears as well, I even got as far as changing opinions I had on a lot of other things prior to watching Zombieland Saga.

This is something I'm likely to get back to later, mostly for the fleshed out and lovable characters.


Overall (7.8/10):

Zombieland Saga proved to be something unlike the generic musical idol series, some would say it's another hit or miss entry, but it really not.

However I try to look at it, its emphasis on well-written characters really is something you rarely see in a lot of good shows, and its plot, in general, is something of a great rewatch-ability value, I myself I'm planning to get into the dubbed version as soon as I'm finished writing this review, because apparently, I need more managers screaming of good mornings and shaving squids up my face for no apparent reason.

Studio Mappa will never cease to astound me with the absurd level of ambition it pours into each and every project it creates. Ever since Zankyou no Terror put them on the map back in 2014 (and even before then, with their debut Kids on the Slope), they have always struck me as a studio willing to go above and beyond, to take on unconventional stories with demanding production requirements, never settling for just being good enough when they had the potential to be so much more. In some ways, that can be to their detriment; while I’ve enjoyed all of their work I’ve seenthus far immensely, I also feel like their ambition almost always outstrips their ability to pull it off at 100% capacity. Yuri on Ice, Zankyou no Terror, and now Zombie Land Saga were all incredibly complex, risky undertakings, and I always get the feeling that the scripts could have used maybe one more pass at the writing table to truly match the challenge they set for themselves. That said, I will always respect a project that shoots for the stars and maybe doesn’t quite stick the landing over a project that plays it too safe to leave any sort of impact. The kind of ambition Mappa exemplifies is the kind of ambition I’d love to see from every other studio out there, the kind of unique and exciting storytelling that makes this medium so valuable. And if Zombie Land Saga isn’t quite the masterpiece it could be, that still shouldn’t take away from just what a fantastically fun, exciting show it is, bursting with imagination and creativity that makes its weaker aspects much more forgivable.


The plot, for those of you who haven’t been keeping abreast of the seasonal discourse and thus haven’t seen this show plastered around every corner, follows young Sakura Minamoto, a high school girl with dreams of being an idol that are promptly dashed when she’s killed by a runaway truck in the first minute of the show. And as she flies in slow-motion through the air, raucous death metal playing over the opening credits, you begin to realize the ingenious bait-and-switch Mappa has caught you in. This isn’t just an idol anime: this is a zombie idol anime. Sakura is resurrected as a zombie, along with six other idols (and idol-adjacents) from various points in Japan’s history, by the mysterious motormouth Kotaro Tatsumi, who plans to turn them into a functioning idol group to serve as a tourism boost for the dilapidated Saga prefecture. And thus, tongue firmly in cheek, the show takes you on a rollicking tour of idol anime’s greatest hits as filtered through the Troma school of schlock horror, and the result is as hectic and inspired as that description might lead you to believe.


Yes, in a word, this show is fun. It’s ridiculously fun. It has such a firm grasp on the mechanics of its own absurd situation that it’s able to start cranking out killer body horror gags and slapstick scenarios straight out of Evil Dead’s slightly peppier cousin right from the word go. The contrast between the usually sterile, pure image of idols and these cute zombie girls with their limbs popping off every odd second is such a refreshing burst of laughing gas, never failing to catch me off guard in the best ways. There’s something kind of lightly transgressive about the whole affair, about letting these focus-group-managed starlets be this wacky and unexpected and weird and outsized and occasionally gross. It grants the entire show an air of unpredictability; for once, I wasn’t really sure how this story was going to play out, even as it starts seguing into more conventional idol trappings in the back half. And when I’m having this much fun not knowing what’s coming next, that speaks volumes about how damn committed this show is to the beat of its own offbeat drum.


The real secret weapon behind Zombie Land Saga’s success, though, is its characters. Franchouchou, as it’s eventually named, is composed of some of the best, most immediately memorable eclectic personalities I’ve seen in quite some time. Sakura is the straight man who’s not afraid to match the intensity of her fellow group members, there’s a pair of more conventional idols who ground the mechanics of the story in their expertise, an expressive little girl with her heart literally beating out of her chest, an actual courtesan with a killer right hook, a badass biker chick who instantly steals every single scene she’s in, and The Legendary Tae Yamada, who might just actually be a conventional mindless zombie, but god dammit, it’s Sailor Moon’s legendary voice actor wrangling an entire character performance out of nothing but growls and grunts, and that’s just plain incredible. But even she’s nothing compared to the sonic wall of explosive mouth diarrhea that is Kotaro Tatsumi. Good. Fucking. God. I have heard Mamoru Miyano’s unhinged vocal stylings before, but this performance just takes it to a whole new level. He is operating at 200% the entire show, rattling out barely coherent orders and inspirational platitudes like a human gattling gun in a voice that swings between “sentient shit-eating grin” and “sloshed drill sergeant” at the drop of a hat. You’d think that would very quickly get annoying, but somehow, Miyano hits the perfect sweet spot between sincerity and self-parody every time, and result will have you bowled over laughing every time he opens his mouth. It’s this cast that endears you to Zombie Land Saga’s unorthodox wavelength, a wacky band of misfits that capture a spirit of camaraderie you can’t help but get swept up in.


Which is good, because while the time we spend just hanging out with these lunatics and watching them do idol stuff is oodles and oodles of fun, I feel that the show isn’t quite as strong in the more emotional moments. Their struggles just feels a little too conventional and perfunctory, especially when compared to how daring and expressive the lighter moments are. To me, Zombie Land Saga doesn’t feel like a show where a subplot as simple as “two group members don’t get along and have to resolve their philosophical argument!” really fits, or where the janky CG used for many of the performance scenes matches the usually expressive-as-hell animation. It’s the faces that really make all the difference: compared to how lively and exaggerated the girls’ expressions are at their best, such as during a gut-busting rap battle in the second episode (yes, you read that right), the stiff, limited movement of their CG models keeps you at far more of a distance at what are supposed to be the climactic emotional high points. And you can really feel that difference, because the few times where the performances are done in traditional animation are easily the best, most evocative moments of the entire show. Especially when, without spoiling too much, one of those performances ends up being the lynchpin of one of the best goddamn coming-out subplots I’ve experienced. If the rest of the emotional storytelling were on that level, then I would feel confident calling this show an outright masterpiece.


As is, though, I can’t feel too disappointed in the show we got, even if it’s maybe a couple of rewrites away from true transcendence. Zombie Land Saga is still absurdly fun, endlessly creative, and bursting with energy, a roller coaster ride of imagination and light subversion that I would definitely love to ride again should a second season be greenlit. Chances are you’ve already checked it out for yourself, but for those of you still on the fence, now’s the time to watch it. I promise you, you won’t regret it.

Although I’ve never watched any idol shows before, Zombieland Saga managed to grab my attention with it’s weird premise and got me hooked with the very first episode.
Story 8/10
The story centres around a group of zombie girls being forced into becoming an idol group by an overzealous manager. Does it sound crazy? Yes. Does it work? Absolutely.
The crazy premise of the show lends itself well in several aspects in regards to the story. The fact that the group is made up of zombie girls is the main source of comedy in the show and can often lead to some funny hijinks. The backstories of thegirls and how they died can deliver some real emotional moments, besides these there are also moments of drama within the group, but these can be either hit or miss. 


Art 6/10

For the most part the anime has a nice and vibrant look to it, with smooth animation. However the animation doesn’t really stand out when compared to other shows. The only time it does stand out is in the use of bad CGI, although it could be argued this is used to parody other shows it comes up too often to excuse.


Sound 9/10

The music the group makes in the show is absolutely amazing and every time I hear it, it gets stuck in my head for several days. The sound design doesn’t particularly stand out either which is often a good sign. Lastly the voice actors do a good job conveying their lines and especially the manager is absolutely amazing at his role.


Character 7/10

The characters in the show all have their own personalities and mannerisms. Most of the main girls get their own arc resulting in some character growth. Of the main cast, the manager is the absolute highlight, stealing any scene he stars in. The side characters feel fun too, but most of them get very little screentime.


Enjoyment 8/10

Zombieland Saga is an absolute joy to watch and a great watch if you’re looking for a fun show that doesn’t take itself too seriously. Even though there are moments where the show lost some steam it remains firm on track and manages to deliver a good series.


Overall 8/10

It knows that it is an idol show that wants to break away from it's niche audience and it tries really hard to be a great anime or atleast a very good one and it fails in some places, if you look at it with a critical eye but like the girls in the show it tries and tries again until it succeeds and I cannot helpbut admire what they did!

Although I would strongly disagree the R17+ rating which is ridiculous, the level of profanity or violence is no where near extreme to justify it. Yet, you have some anime that areborderline H rated and gets a R13+.

FIRST REVIEW, don't judge... plz
Zombieland Saga was a pleasant surprise this season, I went completely blind into it with just a title as reference so I wasn't really expecting for a comedy/idol (first one I've seen) anime but more for an action/horror kind of anime, then when I started watching the first episode my first reaction was "WTF??" and at the same time I was enjoying it. This show hassome of the best characters this season starting with the manager Koutaro Tatsumi his voice actor (Mamoru Miyano) is excellent and every time he talked he made me laugh,*spoiler ahead* btw many people theorized that he was the one that ran over Sakura I actually always thought that he used to know her or had a crush on her when she was alive the way they show it in the show I could have been right *spoiler end*


As for the girls we have everyone with their special little quirk Sakura being main girl as main as can be, Saki a badass, Lily with her heart poking out and being cute af, Junko being the quiet, gentle soul, Ai being litteraly an idol, Yuugiri slapping people left and right, and Tae doing Tae things, overall it is a group that I would like to see a lot more from them.


My main issue with this show is the cg used on the performances, I know that it is kinda of a parody of idol shows and I know that animating a whole performance with dance moves costs a lot of paper, but i thought that at least for the final performance wouldn't be in cg, but nonetheless it wasn't really too bad.


The end left room for a second season and for what i've been seeing apparently this is big in Japan so I'm 90% sure that there will be a second season and I'm hoping for it.

I don't like writing reviews, and I've firmly stated for years that I actively can't stand the idol genre. Yet here I am, writing a review for what's now unironically my favorite anime of all time, despite being an idol anime. Why is that? Well, because Zombieland Saga deserves it.
To quickly go over what the show's all about, since the official synopsis doesn't tell you much, six legendary girls (and Sakura Minamoto) are all dead, and have been brought back to life as zombies with one simple goal. Under the guidance of Kotaro Tatsumi, these seven girls are going to save the Saga Prefecture... asan idol group. I don't quite get it either, but them's the breaks. And now that we've covered that, let's talk about the show.


I'm not gonna sit here and say it's a flawless masterpiece, because masterpiece though I may call it, it ain't perfect. I've got some gripes with the seventh and final episodes in particular that I can't get into for spoiler reasons, but aside from a few eyebrow-raisers here and there, the plot's pretty great. Everything progresses at just the right pace, in just the right way, for just the right reasons. The looks of the show are great (I thought so anyway), I'm no sound design expert but I'm a big fan of the sound in this show, and I'd have to write an entire essay to go over how great the cast is. This is gonna be my new show that I just recommend to absolutely everyone looking for something to watch.


10/10, I'd be totally fine with losing my memories just to experience the whole thing over again.

Comical, engaging and very easy to get into.
ZLS starts from the personal story of Sakura Minamoto who dreamt to be an idol, but meets a rather unfortunate event. It then delves into the fantasy of having the second life as walking corpse with somehow full consciousness and capability to fulfill the said unachieved dream.
The most fascinating is that this show deals with infamous pop culture like death metal and rap but maintain its contrast element. Cute anime girls band together in death metal event. Cute anime girls spitting bars, what more could we want ?!
The only down setter for this show is the CGI. I'mnot sure if its intended to be a parody of other idol show, or just to make the production easier. Yeah its bad, but not bad enough to kill the show. Also the CGI are only in the small percentile of the show (less than 10% so just bear with it already D:).\n\n
We can also feels the love of the production staff towards this show. The passion from the animator and voice actors/actresses truly shape this shows into a beautiful piece of art as proved by the two first episode and the episode 5, it feels they have unlimited budget and go all out with the animation and production quality. It is indeed a candy for mine eyes.\n\n
TLDR: Gorgeous art style , vibrant voice acting, terrific build-up that lead to an satisfying ending, and the most important is lots of hilarious gags that actually cracks me up real hard xD.\n\n
10/10 would rewatch multiple times.

This anime has, hands down, the best opening in anime history. 
Seriously the way this starts it's IMPOSSIBLE not to get your attention. So, now the show has your attention, what does it do with it? 
Story :-
Six lovely ladies are turned into zombies. Their goal is to be teen idles and inject some much needed life into the Saga prefecture in Japan. The irony is very much intended. 
With their fast talking fake it till you make it manager they have to over-come the growing pains of their current predicament, Act as a group, the different personalities and levels of professionalism, their insane manager.


If you haven't realized already this show is parody of girl idol AND horror anime with a little social commentary packaged in regarding how the industry treats teen idols.



Characters :- 



Each of the six girls has her own unique personality that sets her apart and is influenced in part by who she was in life. Sakura Minamoto gets the majority of the screen time as she is the more typical MC in anime... aka Ms. normal but cheerful and pleasant. The manager taking second place though 5 seconds of screen time with him is more than the average mind could handle. 



Art :- 


colourful and upbeat usually though the girls nature allow for some unusual angles. There is a play on the horror genre when needed and the art style shifts to match. CGI pops up after episode two. It's a bit distracting but not horrendous. Just cheap looking... which is how you know they will recycle this particular scene over and over to cut costs. 



Music:- 


A mixed bag. The opening tones in episode one as well as the over the top ones used in that same episode have been the best so far. The rest however are either forgettable or full below average depending on the music genre the show is mocking in that particular episode.



Fun Factor:- 


This show is hilarious. You often have no idea what's going on or what the devil you just watched BUT you always laugh and have a good time. Be it the personality clashes, the sudden zombie attacks (by or on, always a coin toss) or the manager showing up. 



Summery:- 


Zombieland is the definition of an oddball. It effortlessly plays with your expectations and then doesn't go in a different directions so much as through a wall like the cool aid guy. It's weird, it's funny and it's fun. You will easily find at least one of the six girls to root for and your eyes directly go to her in any group setting (Yes I'm talking about the legendary Tae Yamada. GO TAE!) 


It's questionable if the show can keep it's momentum however as the pacing and quirkiness goes down significantly after the second episode...

Just personal scratch.
Advised, possible spoilers.
Opinion & Informal
Art: 7/10
A majority of the art was traditional style while the dance sequences later on were cgi. Outside of the cgi elements, I thought the art quality was nice, clean, and crisp. The few nature showcases looked fine. Not many panoramics or expanses but the generic backgrounds and supporting details looked pretty good though. Interiors were nicely populated and detailed as well. Anatomy and proportions checked out. The zombie version details looked fine. Lots of varied facial expressions that looked fine. Not many impact shots to note. Cgi could look a bit "eh" most of the time, but Iwould have rather had full-framed cgi dance sequences in mediocre quality than nice-looking dance sequences heavy on the selective framing. I admit, there were a few decently nice instances of cgi such as Lily's song, but overall I wasn't too impressed with the cgi work in this show. 


Animation: 7/10

The animation was solid aside from the cgi work. The non-cgi animation looked really good: the headbanging, the dance moves, the facial expression changes, etc. Natural movements such as walking looked good. Motions and gestures looked believable. Supporting effects such as stage lights affecting hue, for example, were nice. My only personal complaint was the stiff cgi: body language looked unnatural and movements looked forced at times. Overall, aside from the cgi which was only a small portion of the show, I thought the animation was solid. 


Characters: 7/10

This show was saved by the its character developments. Despite missing the opportunity to develop Yuugiri and the Legendary Yamada Tae, I was pretty happy with how this show chose to focus on the character developments starting halfway through. Although I found the first one or two episodes interesting enough, my interest began to waver in the early quarter of the show. However, the direction shift to focus on the backgrounds of each of the girls was what changed my initial assumptions about this show. Introducing some sort of baggage to their previous lives and actually resolving it to an acceptable point for most of the girls was excellent. I would have liked a bit more intra-character interactions to strengthen their friendships but I don't know if there would have been enough time for that, so it's fine; I'd like to see it in a sequel if that's ever a thing. What I mean though is that some of the character's stories were a bit isolated to me. For example, Saki's story was resolved through her own guts and that's totally fine, but once her personal story episode was finished the characters that were relevant to it were relegated to simple background cameos. I wanted more of how Junko and Ai formed a deeper friendship than the rest of the cast because their personal stories and resolutions intermingled. I personally would have liked to see Yuugiri's background and I would have killed to see Yamada Tae developed. Overall, I thought that the character designs were well thought out and made each of the characters very distinct and unique. I thought the character dynamics were a bit on the short side, but that was made up for with the focus on  the characters individually. My personal gripe is that I wanted to see more of Tae. 


Plot & Development: 5/10

The initial few episodes were nice and got me interested, but some of the questions that were raised during those times were mostly brushed over by the end. I accepted the explanation for as to how the girls were resurrected into zombies, but I sort of wanted to know how Tatsumi got a hold of the corpses, why they were all in relatively the same condition considering that some were over 100 years old, and how each of the girls were able to stay in relatively the same decomposition state. I accepted the whole "To save Saga" thing, but I was expecting some deeper motivations to be touched upon; the 2 second flashback of Tatsumi's interaction with Sakura implies romance, but that's just it. It was 2 seconds and that's all we got for any explanation of his potential true motivations. It could have been romance, it could have been repaying a debt, pity, etc. Why did Tatsumi have to go about whatever he wanted to do for Sakura by resurrected several other girls? Could Sakura have just attempted to blend into a regular idol group or was it so that Sakura could have something in common with her peers? Plenty of ways to go about explaining everything and they could all be perfectly fine, I'm just pointing some things out. The bar meeting with the mysterious bearded man raised some questions that I had some theories to, but I honestly would have just preferred some clarification or unveiling to that meeting. Overall, I thought the culmination of everything was fine: the girls reached a point closer to their "goal," but I felt like their goal was just stated by Tatsumi. I felt that they sort of just accepted Tatsumi's proposal way too easily, especially for Saki. Moreover, I was left with a lot of "why" and "how" by the end of the show and the way the show wanted to explain (or lack of) everything felt pretty lazy at times to me. 


Music: 7/10

The music was pretty good. I don't normally listen to idol-like or pop-like music, but I was surprised by how catchy I thought the tunes were. I usually don't look for slow-type music too, but I thought Lily's song was nice. I thought it was neat how during the Saga-Rock episode and where the girls were struck by lightning that their song became a different version through changing the vocals to use voice-synthesizer. The reason I gave the music a 7 was because of the neat ways this show handled the music and music style. I liked how it explored different styles. For example, I liked how the first and second episodes, although the girls were ill-prepared, their performances weren't terrible: they used death-rock and freestyle rap which was totally awesome. Overall, I think this show did an excellent job with the way it handled its music and sound. The music was catchy. The soundboard was nice. No sound design to note. OP and ED were fine, not my taste though.


Conclusion: 6/10

The conclusion was fine. It was pretty obvious that they were going to somehow make it in time for their big event and likewise that it would be a hit somehow. The rising up outta a critical situation was also expected. The generic happy ending was fine with me though. At least the show attempted to answer one of the biggest questions during the final episode which was Tatsumi's motivations for "helping?" the girls. I still felt a bit let down that some of the other big plot points weren't addressed fully, but looking at the conclusion through a lighthearted lens, it was good for what it was. 


Overall: 7/10

This show did a good job at introducing and developing a plot encompassing second chances and overcoming personal walls. It was lovely how the story was basically a bunch of girls were given a second chance to overcome their weaknesses or accidents and live lives that they wouldn't have been able to with those weaknesses or accidents. Overall, the art, animation, and music were on point. I personally felt the plot development let me down, but that was overshadowed by the thoughtful character growths. My personal gripe is that I would have liked to see more of the Legendary Yamada Tae. This show is worth considering if you're into idol shows.

I think the first few episodes, which focus on the weird bland of horror and black comedy, are better than the latter ones that's focused on their idol activities, as the idol aspect of the anime is kinda procedural even though it is a lot funnier than in your average idol animes. It picks up when it delves into the backstories of Saki and Lily, which for me is the highlight of the story, but then the ending kinda tapers out again since the conflict at the end feels a little forced. Overall I feel it's a  decent anime and a good change ofpace from all the dark fantasy and harem comedy of late. My thoughts about Lily in particular is on my blog: https://transfelinism.wordpress.com/2019/02/28/transpotlight-the-real-tragedy-of-lily-hoshikawa/
