Zombieland Saga is a pretty entertaining mid-tier anime effort that doesn't quite hit any notable marks, but is a solid time throughout. The kind of show that, if you know enough Japanese, is a really good anime to half-pay-attention to while you're doing the dishes or something.
The whole thing veers pretty wildly between a ridiculous satire of idol culture, literally resurrecting dead people to churn out a new idol group for some publicity, and then a legitimately emotional and sappy idol zero-to-hero series. The two sides don't mesh that well and the whole show ends up being a bit schizophrenic as a result, but there'llbe something for you to latch on no matter your sensibilities, unless your sensibilities include realistic characters with good character arcs.


The characters are all very strong, though only about half of them get much of a story arc and none of them change personality much through the series (besides some spoiler elements). You'll probably end up really liking one or two of them, but overall it's a pretty standard lineup of quirky characters. 


Lots of funny moments throughout the series, even if the plot sticks to exactly what you'd expect out of a series featuring an idol group starting in the middle of the boonies. The zombie element allows for a lot more brutal violence against already-undead people, and the hijinks of hiding their zombie nature creates some really good moments. The comedy is by far the best part of the show.


However, the idol stuff is pretty middling. All of the idol performances, except for one, are rendered in terrible CGI. I thought that was part of the joke at first, but by the end it was pretty clear it was a cost-saving measure and a really ugly one at that. None of the songs were memorable either, definitely not compared to the very good OP and ED. There aren't that many performances in the show, maybe six or seven, but you'll usually be spacing out when they happen because they take away from the comedic elements.


Of course, there's also some drama and sappy teambuilding efforts. The drama, ramped up in a couple key episodes in the second half, is generally very good, dealing with some sensitive topics and delving deep into a couple of these undead characters in ways that hit hard-- one specific episode actually got me tearing up and it was a bit embarrassing. But the drama is always undercut by the formulaic "Let's Ganbatte!" stuff with the idol group working together as a team to pass the obstacles before them. Because of the parody elements, and because of the legitimate dramatic elements, the idol teamwork stuff is really boring and takes away from the rest. 


So Zombieland Saga is a real mixed bag. Chances are, there's something in there for you to enjoy, no matter your taste. However, there'll also be plenty of things for you to dislike as well. It won't stand the test of time, but it was a good enough show that I'd say I enjoyed watching it. Which is good enough for me.

First off, I want to say that I really wanted to enjoy this show. I really did. But when I found it a chore to watch the next episode, I just couldn't
Let's start with the premise of the story. 6 girls that died in different periods of time are revived by Tatsumi Kotaro to become idols and save the town of Saga. Sounds interesting enough right? That's what I thought in the first episode. I was thinking "alright this is gonna be pretty good and funny." Instead I got a boring show with boring characters whom I all despise besides the manager, Kotaro. 
Speaking moreon the characters, I didn't like any of them besides Kotaro, but most of his punchlines were HAHAHAHA I'm being mean and yelling at the zombie girls!!!!! All of the idol characters annoyed me and none of them were that interesting to me


Now let's get to the comedy part. Now I understand that comedy wasn't really the main goal of the show but it was pretty obvious that they were trying to land jokes and just failed miserably. I spoke about Kotaro's jokes but "The Legendary Yamada Tae's" jokes through some of the show were just her making noises and OMG ZOMBIE GIRL ISNT AWAKE YET AHAHAHAHAHAHA and it just really got on my nerves that they would sink to such low levels of comedy.


Now to the infamous episode 3 where they used atrocious CG to "make fun of" other idol shows but it just came across as them using horrible CG. It made it look worse than the stuff they were trying to make fun of.


All in all, I gave it a 4 just because I wanted to get it done but it felt like such a chore watching the next episode, purely because of how much I didn't enjoy it.

Zombieland Saga (ZLS), a show that poses as a zombie horror show, which is revealed to be an absurdist comedy, which is ultimately revealed to be idol show propaganda. The show is hilarious at times, sad at others and a bit hard to look at, at other times.
The story’s quality fluctuates, starting with a bang, there are numerous laugh out loud jokes that just keep on giving. Even if you don’t care for the direction the show takes later on, the first 2 episodes are most definitely worth a watch for their laughs. ZLS begins with fantastic humour, yet by episode 3, it fades away,reducing what was once laugh out loud jokes, to slight exhalation of air from one’s nose jokes, the hilarity not to reappear until episode 5. In its place is a generic friendship and teamwork plot line that’s been seen countless times before in the likes of generic school club room shows. It’s serviceable, but leaves a lot to be desired. But! Do not be mistaken, the series doesn’t deteriorate any further, it’s absurd hilarity from the beginning (and episode 5) is toned down for the rest of the series, yet in its place a handful of well crafted episodic adventures surrounding individual characters from the group, that make it very hard to pick a favourite character... if it weren’t for a certain individual I’ll discuss later.. These character episodes fluctuate in quality too, and they make up the bulk of the story, one being my favourite, and another leaving a lot to be desired. The drama presented in each episode is usually familiar, repackaged in a zombie theme, competently made, but not incredible. It is where the story explores new unique drama that the story excels (ie. episode 8). Overall, the story is a mixed bag, and a little messy.


Each and every idol and a very special producer could all be a different persons favourite character in ZLS. They are all highly likeable, and range from purely comedic to respectable characters. As a fan of ZLS’s comedic elements the most, the Producer; Koutarou and Tae the mindless zombie we’re my favourite characters. Koutarou’s manic rants, pep talks and complete confidence in his and the girls success make him a spectacle to watch, whilst Tae keeps the brain (or squid) hungry, droning, chomping zombie spirit of the original zombie premise alive, always inserting herself into the story at the worst (and in the context of a comedy show; best) times. Protagonist Sakura is fun to root for, passionate and a little awkward, developing and learning along the way. The other characters are once again - a mixed bag. Most received an individual episode that explored their character, and their deaths, (a large source of trauma for zombies) which elevated their characters from the generic stereotypes seen in hundreds of other shows, like the cutesy, squeaky young girl, the esteemed senpai or the brash sporty (or in this case - bikie) girl to engaging and multifaceted characters. The degree of which this occurred differed between the girls however. One received no development, others remained stagnant, unchanged by death. Yet a few changed, and developed post death, creating characters that I will remember for some time. Overall, all had their comedic and their dramatic moments, but they ranged from generic to unique.


The production, of course, is a mixed bag. Character designs were good, each character was unique and distinguished from one another, but nothing too incredible. The art style, backgrounds and animation were all fairly generic, with little to comment on. Serviceable. The idol performances were animated in 3D like most other idol shows, yet unfortunately, ZLS’s 3D was very poorly integrated, jarring and detracted from the performances. The voice acting saved the day however, as the VA’s put their all into it, and Mamoru Miyano had the time of his life as Koutarou the producer, enthusiastically screaming and whimpering in the best way possible. The idol performances were good to listen to, the cutesy pop music is not something I am personally into, but I could appreciate it. The death metal and rap battle however, I most certainly was into, and they were both highlights of the series, the rap in particular flowed very well, and the translators even ensured that the rhyming remained in the subtitles, which was very much appreciated. 


Zombieland Saga, whilst at times left me disappointed, ultimately left me thankful. Thankful for the incredible humour dispersed throughout, for the eternally fantastic Koutarou, and for a pretty decent tale of teamwork, friendship and self confidence, no matter how done to death the message is.

I don't really like idol anime....but I really liked this one. It's good at taking some of the idol troupes and flipping them on their heads. That's not to say it doesn't fall into these troupes as the show goes on, but somehow it all just worked out. 
The Zombie angle was enough to keep the early episodes interesting and make up for the surprisingly bad CG dance numbers. But as the show goes on you learn more about each of the characters before they became undead. The characters and their past become the more interesting feature of the show and is usually interrupted byidol nonsense. By the end, the show has told a wonderful story about failure and overcoming it.


I wouldn't say that I Highly recommend the show if you're not into idol stuff, but I will say it was definitely one of the sleeper hits of 2018 and I'm glad I went back and finished it. 


-oh it also has one of the best OPs of the year.

Zombieland Saga had the chance to become one of he best, if not THE BEST idol show out there. The start of the show was shocking, but hilarious. The zombie concept left a lot of room for unique comedy, and the cast of odball characters from different eras (most of whom didn't even want to become idols) really set the show apart! Deathmetal and rap battles, weird promotions and oddjobs to get the group's name out there, it was all very promising in it's creativity and stark difference from other idol shows.
Unfortunately, the show started to get into formulaic and predictable stuff mid-season. The episodesregarding the character's backgounds, the horrendous 3D concerts, it was all pretty bland. Even the later episodes about the group dynamic and the main character were less and less unique. Even if we take all the objectively bad things out, it's still just wishy-washy idol stuff you can watch anywhere else, probably better. Where are the different music genres from the earlier episodes? Where is that crazy energy that carried the show?\n
Unfortunately, Zombieland Saga ended up as another trend-follower instead of the trend-setter I wanted it to be. It's still a quirky show about zombie idols, and I think it's still worth watching, but the show didn't deliver on the promise of it's great early episodes.

I really toiled with the rating for this show. I've been in a slump with work, and so I only was able to watch about 4 shows at a time rather than my usual 8 that I whittle down. As a result, I dropped less shows but kept with ones that I would have dropped otherwise. Overall, I'm not sure if it was a show I would have dropped or not, and I'm torn enough I wish I could give it a 6.5.
Off the bat I have to admit my bias. I've never watched an idol show before this. I've been aware of them andtheir effect on merchandising, but I've never participated in them. For me, that's the strength in this show. It's the first idol show that's grasped me and kept me interested, even if only as a minor participant. I'll just organize this into story, animation, character, and sound.


Story: The story is pretty simplistic in itself. Not many answers are given as to why they're brought back, but I have a heavy feeling that this is because it's a "go read the manga" type of show. This isn't bad in itself (I'm waiting with baited breath for the Kaguya anime, but I'm expecting the same treatment), however, the story then had to revolve around a minor arc for each of the starts of the show. I'll be honest, this was the strongest part of the show. A lot of these girls arcs are heartfelt and honest, and give a great insight to who they were before they died and who they are now. Almost everyone dies with regrets, and they were some of the lucky few who got to try and rectify these regrets on their own. There is obviously and overarching story related to the manager, however it's unclear if a S2 will come to carry this along.


Animation: I'll be blunt, the animation/art will get a fair rating from me due to the use of CGI. Honestly, if this anime just had the story going for it, it would be a non-issue. However the non-CGI animations of this show were absolutely phenomenal. I could only top it this year with the animations I saw from Slow Start for a fairly mundane show about "cute girls doing cute things". These crisp animations were then brought down by most of the performances they did when CGI was brought into the picture. It's sad too, because in and idol show I feel the actual performances are a crucial part to nail. If they do a S2 and remove that portion, it could easily be a 7 or 8 overall ranking for me. The CGI was the biggest turn off for me in the show, because once you reach these crucial crux's of each characters arc you have to deal with these lumbering and unnatural movements of animation that completely takes you out of the show.


Character: This intertwines with story, but, I really enjoyed most of the characters of this show. I don't want to go into too much detail due to spoilers, however each character has a fleshed out personality, voice, and even time period from which they hail. Some seem there for comic relief, but then show they are very dedicated to the group as a whole. Others are consistently the "rocks" of the group that many go to for support. Even the accents and dialogue they put forth are related to their identity as idols.


Sound: This will be the part where I'm the least knowledgeable. I thought the songs were decent (from what I can tell from subtitles), yet I am also not an idol follower. The songs might have also been tainted for me from the CGI animations (another gripe at it), which brings what could have been very emotional scenes down for me. Still, I did find them somewhat catchy, and I enjoyed when they delved into other styles that weren't really "pop" music.


Overall, this show is probably worth the time for someone who does watch idol shows. However, I'm not confident in all aspects I've put forth. As far as character development and animation, I can confidently say the majority is great and worth your time. To say the entire show is perfect though, would overlook many issues I had with the CGI and the pretty shoestring story which seems like an obvious manga advertisement.

This is, and will probably ever be, the only moe idol show that I'm okay with watching.
Like many others who started watching this during the time it started airing, I had no idea what this anime would be about. Despite all that, my curiosity drove me to watch the first episode, and I'm so glad that it did. If you don't want to read an indepth review that objectively analyses this anime, just to find out whether it's worth watching or not, then here's your answer.
Watch it. Like, right now..... GO GO GO GO GO GO GO!!!
*Non-spoiler review*
Now if you're still here despite that, here'sthe full length review. The story of Zombieland Saga isn't a complex one, but it does leave many gray areas for you to explore. Several aspects about the events that led to the story told within the anime are left out, but it doesn't feel empty and forgotten. Over the course of the series, small hints are given through the revelations or flashbacks of certain characters, that do serve to clear up some mysteries, yet still add more questions to the mix. It certainly isn't a story-driven anime, but it is definitely not one that completely ignores the fundamentals of story-telling. You don't feel like any of the episodes are fillers, because they all are important to either the story or character development. Now as for the ending, it is certainly an open-ended one that suggests a season 2 of this series, so if you end up enjoying the anime, don't fret over it not getting a season 2. The comedy however, was top tier. 10/10


The art style for Zombieland Saga is rather stylistic. Since a big part of this show is the comedy as well, I believe this art style fits well with the violent, fluid motions of slap-stick comedy, made possible due to the fact that they're all zombies. I personally thought that it was great, and have no problem with it. However, the majority of performance scenes were done using CGI, which is quite noticeable. It does break the immersion a little, but it isn't done badly. Just the fact that the change from 2D to 3D is far too apparent within this anime. I do have to add though that the choreography was done rather well, and I enjoyed seeing the girls perform. Apart from that, the character designs are all unique. You'll definitely be able to recognize all the characters, despite what they're wearing or doing. I believe each character design is a very accurate representation of their personalities, so it all ends up being a fitting match.


Now, for probably the most important part of the show, the sound. I think that the voice acting was absolutely great in this anime, but the songs were a bit lack luster for me. I'm not saying that they were bad. Rather, they were all quite enjoyable to listen to. However, I can't remember a single one of them after finishing the anime, which could mean that I have really bad memory, or the tracks just weren't unique in anyway to your standard run of the mill J-Pop. I can assure you that it isn't low-quality, but I personally didn't find it amazing. Whether or not you'll enjoy it though, is only for you to decide.


Each character within the group, and the manager, were all very interesting and played an important role in either progressing the story, or developing other characters. You don't feel like there is a single main character to the story, because they all seem to be a very active part of the anime, plus the show doesn't focus on only one member of the group, but switches between all of them depending on the current arc. There is a lot of character development in both a positive and negative way, that all makes sense within the current part of the story being told. They each have strengths and weaknesses, but they all learn to overcome it by relying on each other and moving forward together. I might not be able to remember all of them as time goes on, but I will certainly remember the legendary Yamada Tae for all eternity. Why? Well, you'll just have to watch to find out...


To conclude this review, I would have to say that this series was extremely fun to watch. It was like a breath of fresh air, adding even greater enjoyment to an already incredible season. I will certainly remember the first episode, and this series as being the one and only moe idol show that I will have ever watched, and enjoyed immensely. Please, I urge you to watch this show immediately. It doesn't matter if you like idol shows or not. I can guarantee that you'll find atleast one thing from this anime that you'll enjoy.


Thank you for reading this review! I hope you enjoy watching Zombieland Saga as much as I did.

When I first saw this anime, I thought it was something like cute girls surviving a Zombie apocalypse. Heck even the trailer and description made it look like a Zombie Apocalypse. I thought cool, sounds like a nice anime. How wrong was I. Instead of guns and explosions, we get Zombie idolru and truck-kun. It was still a somewhat decent anime and I really laughed through the whole anime, and at the same time shedding some tears through the way.
Story:
Well, first episode in, and the main character already died in Truck-kun's hands. 10/10 best opening for an anime ever. And Sakura revives as a Zombieand ends up with other Zombies becoming idolrus in order to save Saga. The story was enjoyable and at the same time laughable with all the meme scenes :v. I really liked how they showcased each and every character's backstory so that we can understand the characters better and fall in love with them. And I also like how Kotarou is always pushing and encouraging the MCs to persevere and become great idolrus, despite using unconventional methods to do so. And in the end, they did it, and the story continues, as there'll most probably be a 2nd season to Zombieland Saga.

Rating: 8/10


Animation: 

For the first time ever, even though Zombieland Saga used CGI for the idol performances, it was actually quite good and not cancerous like other animes. I have to give credit to MAPPA for producing great CGI animation quality. Other than that, the character and background animations were great.

Rating: 7.5/10


Music: 

Opening was so memey heck I loved the opening. The songs for the idol performances were also good I liked it. 

Rating: 7.8/10


Characters: 

The character development for Zombieland Saga was good I feel that every character had enough development to appeal to the viewers. Almost one episode per character, and for Sakura's case, 2-3 episodes for her. Kotarou himself had a quite a thorough development where we see that beneath his rude appearance, he has a soft side. Also, I must give a shout out to the best character of the series, TRUCK-KUN!

Rating: 8.6/10


Overall, an anime I enjoyed more than I originally thought. Can't wait for the 2nd season of Zombieland Saga!


Final rating: 8/10

Don't let the fact that this is an idol anime deter you from watching it. It has everything you need to enjoy it: a great set of characters, each with a unique personality and at least decent backstory; a mysterious element, great songs and decent plot; outstanding artwork (even the CGI scenes are great IMO); and, well, cute girls doing cute things. Even though there is an over-the-top idiot (with excellent voice acting), the characters are well-written and they go through actual character development. The story itself is about overcoming your individual weaknesses by being part of a group, which is pretty general, but reallywell executed.

This is just something everyone needs to watch or atleast know. There really isn't much to say what this show is. You just need to see for yourself.
 It has fantastic characters(Miyano Mamoru is a blessing to the ears), and every single VA is doing the best they could do and it's just fun to listen to them.
 Music is a total banger(would listen to every damn song like 20billion times), the VA's singing is just fantastic to listen to, they all have such good voices.
Art and animation are also great(the cgi did not bother me whatsoever, it looked perfectly fine and it's really notthat noticable if you are enjoying the songs to the fullest), it's also very colourful.\n
Enjoyment level over 9000. Would rewatch anytime.\n
Give it a try!

They've done it. They've finally made an idol anime interesting. For so long idol anime have all been a cookie cutter format of getting a bunch of highschool age, or somehow younger for whatever reason, girls to form a group of misfit idols that somehow takes the world by storm with their 3D animated dancing segments. Zombieland saga just threw that template out the window in the first episode. Not gonna spoil anything, but the first 2 episodes of this series really make a statement about not being like other idol anime.
The casting choice of Miyano Mamoru was top notch, having just come off aSteins Gate binge I'm fairly biased towards his characters. His energy just brings a whole new level of entertainment to the show that would be difficult for any other voice actor to match. \n
While most of the characters do share common characteristics with other idol anime, just the fact that they're zombies makes them infinitely better.\n
Overall, expectations completely blown away. This one's a winner.

Story:
     Zombieland Saga.. as a comedy it's pretty good with the start our starting MC Sakura wanted to fulfill her dreams of becoming an idol. So at the start my interest was getting pretty low because I have seen a lot of similar anime, but as soon as it starts they queue the happy music and then out of nowhere shes hit by a truck which was pretty funny honestly. After that incident I was going to give this anime the benefit of the doubt. I just finished episode 4 and the story has a good flow and so far noplot holes. With that I give the story an 8 out of 10.


Art:

     The art in my opinion is well done for the tone of the anime, but when it comes to the CGI usage it isn't very characteristic to the show it almost seems forced. When I first saw the CGI in episode 3 I was laughing because of how poor it was but I've also taken the fact it is a comedy so I accepted as part of the show. The CGI in episode 4 was better but still had some way to go, but other than the CGI the art is well done not lazy nor looks hastily drawn in most scenes there is a detailed well drawn background which don't see in a lot of anime. With that I give the art a 7 out of 10.


Sound:

     The sound is a strong point in the show but of course without the great sound quality this wouldn't be much of a music genre show; the voice tracking with the characters are on point and the singing is great. The background sounds which not many really appreciate or notice is excellent. I know that was short but my rating for the sound is a 10 out of 10.


Characters:

     The characters are well done each seem to have their backgrounds and have their own diverse personalities, and I know that this is only on episode 4 but hopefully there will be further character development. Without the character development the audience will end up losing care for the characters leaving the ending just another empty ending. If they get good character development then I will edit my score but for now I'm leaving it with an 8 out of 10 due with the fact the anime still has another 8 more episodes and with the diversity of the characters.


Enjoyment:

     I really did enjoy watching this and I plan to finish this ZLS in the future and right now I have had a great impression from the show, it's funny and the songs are great to listen to. The characters are relatable with daily life problems which I enjoy and all in all its fun light hearted show of few I don't always watch. With that I give the enjoyment a 10 out of 10.


Overall:

     Overall the show has a good mostly original story, with great art of exception to its CGI, beautiful sound and voice tracking, and diverse and interesting characters. With that being said I give the Overall Score of this anime Zombieland Saga a 8 out of 10. The score will change based on what happens in the future just keep working on developing the characters and art and I'll gladly move this to a 9 or 10 out of 10.


     With that thanks for reading my review on Zombieland Saga this is my first review I've ever done so far and I plan to continue to make more reviews in the future have a great day.
